data.message: I did a histogram out of the post data. Most people post 0-2 times, with a very consistent distribution between no posts and two posts. After two posts, contribution drops suddenly to almost zero.

Here is a graph on the average word count of  posts and average word count of comments. I learned that the word counts were not significantly different when people make a comment versus a post. Comments typically had fewer words per post (33) while posts had more on average (41).

I created two graphs: one showing the top 5 words used in posts, and one showing the top 5 words used in comments. What I’ve learned from these two graphs is that they are very similar: both have the words ‘virtual’, ‘file’, and ‘machine’. Also, that people are more polite when writing comments because the word ‘thanks’ shows up 13 times more than in the posts. :D

I am working on part one of the feed processor. When I try to call the nested dictionary I keep getting a key error. I am not entirely sure why since I have a default value when I create my nested dictionary. I've tested to see if dictionary[person] works in the new if statement, and it does. Am I calling the nested dictionary wrong? Ideas/suggestions?

Hi Mallory -- the KeyError: 0 means that you are passing in 0 as a key in that code (probably as postCount but possibly also person) and it can't find a corresponding value. 

I'd approach troubleshooting this by:
1) printing the dictionary 
2) printing person and postCount
and making sure they are each what you expect them to be. My guess is that you're passing in the count (0) when you want to be passing in the key that lets you access the count.

For the last question about counting the words in posts and comments (hw4-feedprocessor); are we suppose to count the blanks as well? Because I am having this in my dictionary " {'': {'posts': 11, 'comments': 65}".
These should be removed for this assignment -- I removed them before writing my CSV file.
ok Thanks!
How do i stop printing "None" at the end of most of my print statements?

For these, double check whether your *function* is doing the printing as well, in which case you may have an extra print statement that is printing the implicit return value of the function (none).

For example:
def printSquare(x):
      print x*x

print printSquare(2)

will print:
4
None

because the print happens in the function, and then the print in the print printSquare(2) line prints the None returned by printSquare()
(facebook removed my indentation - print x*x should be indented)
Boom, knowledge aquired
thanks. fixed it

When processing the word frequencies for the freq.csv there's two pieces of text that seem to produce undesirable results (see images). I'm guessing this is due to parenthesis sandwiching a comma (see excerpts below) in the hw4feed.txt. Do we need to address this issue?

Excerpts:
wordFreq("hw3feed.txt",'post')
wordFreq("hw3feed.txt",'post')["anyone"]

I handled this by (certainly over)using the replace function.

word = word.replace('(', '').replace(')', '').replace("\"", '').replace("'", '').replace(",", '')

EDIT: See below for a better solution.

We won't take off if you have unescaped commas, but we might as well use this to have a bit of an example in data cleaning.

In CSV files, you can escape a comma by enclosing the whole field (e.g., our "word") in quotes. So our line would look something like:
"word",postcount,commentcount

That, however, causes a new problem -- since the same lines have quotes in them as well. You can escape quotes in CSV files by using another quote before it. So if we had a word: someFunc("some string"), we could escape those by using two quotes: someFunc(""somestring"")

or, to put it all together, the line, if opened in a text editor, would look like:
"someFunc(""somestring"")",0,1 

The code for replacing double quotes with double double quotes is: 
word.replace("\"","\"\"")
Got it, thanks!

The chart I produced compares the contributions of the students and teaching staff in the Facebook feed. It shows the total number of posts and comments made by their respective groups. This simple comparison shows that the vast majority of the posts are being made by the students. Support, in the form of comments, is being given at similar rates by both group. This show that the students are generating the conversations and both teachers and students appear to be sharing in the effort to resolve issues.

Hello! I am working on part 8 of the FeedProcessor assignment. I keep getting this error and do not quite understand how the test lines of code work with the code I have written. In particular, I am confused how the word ["anyone"] gets linked with the function without parameters in the function.

Hi Mallory - in this line of code, the return value of wordFreq("hw3feed.txt",'post') gets substituted in. Your function, if working properly, will return a dictionary (and from this error, it looks like it is).

wordFreq("hw3feed.txt",'post')["anyone"] then refers to the value corresponding to "anyone" in that dictionary. The line compares that value with 9 to see if it matches. There is also a second comparison, for eclipse and 5.

From the error, it looks like the returned dictionary does not contain the key "anyone."  If I were debugging, the first place I'd start is to call wordFreq("hw3feed.txt","post") and print the return value to see if it looks like what I expect, i.e., add a line before the test lines:
print wordFreq("hw3feed.txt","post")
I get the same error, I did what you suggested and called the function to print the return value. All I get is an empty dictionary

In that case, my next step would be to add some print statements in my for loop to make sure it is actually iterating through the file. 

If it isn't, the next thing I would check is whether I'm re-opening the file *within* the function (recall that each time we read the file, it "consumes" it, so we have to re-open it)

If it is, then I'd look at the dictionary as I am building it (inside the for loop). Is it adding things? If not, can I figure out why?
I keep getting this error when I run part 8. Would anyone be able to tell me what it means?

Hi Pooja -- I think this is referring to the variable "file" -- which corresponds to <type 'file'> in Python. Double check your variable and a parameter names for the file name / file handle in wordFreq()

Hi - have you moved any of the files? VirtualBox is somewhat brittle with how it handles moving any of the files.

Some students have been able to fix this issue by removing the virtual machine from the VirtualBox manager (right click on it in the list, and then 'remove') and then adding it again by double-clicking on the vbox file in your Mint directory. All of your work is contained in the vdi file, so as long as you still have that, you should be able to re-add the machine and have it pick up right where you left off. Just make sure it doesn't delete when you remove the machine, if it asks!

I've been getting this error, while running hw3feedprocessor.py the problem I'm having is specifically in part 8. I was wondering if someone could tell me what this error means

hey! the error itself means that you're trying to "get" some data (just as array[0] would "get" the 1st element of the array), but the reason it's not getting anything is because your object basically doesn't exist/have any data to pull from. in this case the if statement is trying to get ['anyone'] from your wordFreq(fname, 'post) - that means your wordFreq isn't a proper dictionary.

one possible solution is that you're not returning anything! if you don't return a dictionary, there is no dictionary object to get data from. if you are returning something, i would go back and check out how you set up your dictionary. hope this helps!
There's a typo in hw3feedprocessor.py part 4 - I was inconsistent in variable names between comment and comments. You can just pick one.

This is splitting only whitespace:

Spaces are also characters - remember that split() removes the white space it splits on.

is there a good way to make sure the .py files I am submitting is the committed and changed version of the homework?

I'm not sure what shows up in the view you get on Canvas, but at least in our grading view, Canvas shows the python file as plain text.

The most common mistake in past years has been uploading from Homeworks_OriginalVersion, so double check that (a) you've saved the Python file in Eclipse or your other editor and (b) that you're uploading from the right folder.

Also, if you continue committing and pushing to Bitbucket (please do!), you can check on the web that you've successfully sent your code to the repository. On the web, you can go to your repository, git, source, and then the homework file. This also gives you a timestamped backup, just in case anything goes wrong with the Canvas submission.

Hello,

The getHW.sh has a small issues that I would like to highlight. After some testing I discovered that if the files/folders in ./CourseFiles/hcde310a16/Homeworks are altered or moved, and getHW.sh is run again, the git fetch only seems to check whether the correct subdirectories exist and not the files. And if getHW.sh is run with a number parameter, it's written to simply copy the .py files from ./CourseFiles/hcde310a16/Homeworks to ./Homeworks. The result is that when the latter is called, the former files do not exist and the homework cannot be fetched. But if getHw.sh is called again, it does not replace the .py files because the subdirectories do exist.

I tried a few different options and discovered that git fetch followed by git reset --hard solves the problem on my computer because it always overrides everything in ./CourseFiles/hcde310a16. That shouldn't be a problem because the user is asked if they want to override the Homework files when copying them over anyways. The git reset --hard seems to not work on the Linux mint vm. Maybe one of the TAs can do some testing with this?

Thanks Eric. I've looked through, and a couple of notes:

=Virtual Machine =
This seems to be working as expected. The git pull is outside the conditional and will run regardless of whether an argument is provided.

It does have the issue that if you delete a hw directory within CourseFiles/Homeworks, it won't reappear -- this is git performing as expected. This should be okay since the CourseFiles directory is meant to mostly be left alone with homeworks instead being done in ~/Homeworks. 

I was able to run git reset --hard within the hcde310a16 directory (note: not encouraging this in general, since it'll overwrite any changes you have made to lecture files).

= getHW.sh on Canvas (for macOS) = 
I've looked here too -- the git pull is outside the the conditionals, so the git fetch should be running regardless of whether it is run with our without the number.

So it seems like the only issue that occurs is when files or directories are moved from within ./CourseFIles/hcde310a16/Homeworks?

It's also possible I'm misunderstanding, so please let me know if so.

Sean

Thanks for the quick reply! I do think we're on the same page. I didn't know that its not supposed to replace the files so I suppose nothing is wrong there. Yes in theory there shouldn't be any missing homework directories but I've encountered some cases where some of them are in fact missing, and the student was not able to pull homeworks as a result. I am just wondering if that base could be covered in case it happens again.

Got it, thanks - I'll give it some thought and test some things; also adding Michael to the thread to think about it. I've tried to pick the right set of tradeoffs between which mistakes are possible vs. prevented with this script, but knowing which issues come up can help us rethink it.
Thank you Sean!

My two cents,
The way things are done can leave some confusion. With that said I have noticed that for some the distinction between the class repository that getHW pulls from(CourseFiles/hcde310a16) and the copy folders(i.e. Homeworks, Homeworks_OrginalVersions) allows for an initial understanding of a couple of the more core “Git rules”. Ideally, if the system is used correctly people shouldn’t have to do too much else other than running ‘getHW.*’ To do that however, sometimes some further explanation of Git is necessary.

Eric it seems like you are adding a bit of customization to your system, which is great! If you want to stop by office hours to show us what you’ve done we would be happy to take a look and perhaps change the class copy of ’getHW.*’ script to make the system as a whole more intuitive. If this interests you I have intended office hours are from 12-1pm and alternatively have free time before and after that :-)

Hi everyone working on wishing their on environments!

We made a small bug fix to ‘getHW.*’ (both .sh and the .bat files). Both files have been re uploaded to canvas with the fix. The feature we added allows the macOS and Windows versions of ‘getHW.*’ to mirror the process that is used in mint. It’s not necessary to change to this file so if you are happy with your current setup, please keep using it.

New "getHW.*" file:

Is anyone else receiving this same error? "Trying to open a VM config 'C:/Users/Bonnie/Downloads/VM310/Mint/HCDE310-linuxmint-18-64bit.vbox' which has the same UUID as an existing virtual machine"

Any chance you have more than one instance of VirtualBox open?

Same problem here. I've deleted all the extra files, but this is still popping up

hey all, I've done some testing and found a solution for you. it is a bit of a hassle, so if needed I can look at it in class. for those who want to try it now (I've only tested on windows!), here it is:

1) Open up your command prompt (by typing cmd in the start menu and clicking on it). Navigate to where you installed virtual box - if you didn't move it around, you can type

cd C:\Program Files\Oracle\VirtualBox\

into your cmd.

2) Now, you'll have to copy and paste 

VBOXMANAGE.EXE internalcommands sethduuid "DIRECTORY"

into your cmd, except replace DIRECTORY with the HCDE310 .vdi file location. Make sure you keep the quotes! for example, my file is located at C:\Users\Alex\Downloads\mint2\HCDE310-linuxmint-17.1-cinnamon-64bit.vdi, so I would type 

VBOXMANAGE.EXE internalcommands sethduuid "C:\Users\Alex\Downloads\mint2\HCDE310-linuxmint-17.1-cinnamon-64bit.vdi"

This changes the UUID - you're getting this error because you've moved the location of the VM and are using the same image. virtual box is funny that way.

This is slightly complex, so feel free to ask for clarification! Otherwise, I can help you in/after class tomorrow.

Is anybody else having trouble with Virtual Machine and their internet connection? My internet was working fine until I tried to use the Internet through the Virtual Machine, just spend an hour talking to the Internet guy - it shows as my connection being fine but nothing on Internet will load. Closed out of VM, restarted multiple times, etc. All other devices work fine on the Internet... anybody know of a solution?

Does your Internet connection work fine other than in the Virtual Machine? 

If so, it's probably the case that Virtual Machine need to be configured a little differently on your system. In VirtualBox, select Devices -> Network from the menu, and then Network settings. You should have a drop down, options that *usually* work for are:
NAT
NAT Network
NAT Bridged 

one student last year found that NAT didn't work at first, changed it to something else, and that didn't work -- and then changed it back to NAT, only to have it start working.

So maybe try those three, and then go back to whatever it whatever it was on if it doesn't start working. If that doesn't work, let us know what operating system you are on and we can do some more reading  to see if that prompts any more ideas.

Any input on whether having Python on the virtual machine vs an IDE is more of the "industry standard?"

What do you mean by "on"? In my experience, most people write their code in an IDE and then test/deploy through some command line interface. Usually it's up to personal preference though. Although I'd say learning to use the command line is pretty important.

Yeah -- similar to Samuel's experiences, once you start developing production apps, people tend to develop in whatever environment is comfortable for them (or specified by their employer) and then test/run it elsewhere.

Later in the quarter, we'll get to Google Cloud SDK (formerly App Engine), which uses virtual machines to run production environments. Amazon Web Services Elastic Compute Cloud follows a similar approach. This is a common approach, for a mix of reasons. The top in my experience are: (1) you can customize the virtual system to your application's, (2) you can limit the amount of resources your virtual system uses on a shared physical machine,  (3) if you (or someone else using the same physical machine) writes a buggy app that crashes the system, it (typically) crashes just the virtual machine, rather than the entire system, and (4) it's easy to launch other "instances" of the virtual machine on other systems, so you can handle sudden spikes in traffic. 

Approaches like that are common for web apps now.  But I've also had some projects (typically remote collaborations) where it was easiest to create a virtual machine and run it on our own laptops, just like in class. For small scale data analysis, you also often write and run the code on the same system -- we do this a lot in our research, and many people do that for weblog analysis on small or medium sites (but this quickly becomes impractical when you get to Facebook-scale data).

Docker (https://www.docker.com/what-docker) has also become increasingly popular, and we're using it for some projects in our research now. A big difference is that VirtualMachines require you to run an entire guest operating system (in 310, this is the Linux Mint distribution), which has a lot of overhead in spaced resources. Docker relies on the host operating system (Windows, OS X, or whatever else you are already running) but still sets up containers with customized environments and resource environments. It's also increasingly supported by cloud hosting services (e.g., Google Cloud).
I see. That makes a lot of sense - thanks for the help!
